item.title: Aelec Bluetooth Headphones for iPhone
item.description:
Since Apple decided to drop the headphone jack on their latest phones, I thought I would try out some bluetooth headphones. Amazon suggested the aelec 5030. These have a built in battery and I liked that the earbuds are connected to eachother (left and right) by a wire so they won’t be too easy to loose. I imagined jogging or working out without having to worry about a cord connecting my ears to the phone. I hate doing abs and having to have the phone in my pocket. Jogging isn’t so bad with regular headphones, but the swinging wire can be a pain. On the treadmill it can be downright dangerous. More than once my arms have hit the headphone wire and yanked my phone off the treadmill controls and onto the belt where I nearly tripped on the phone.

I’m a fan of earbud headphones. I like that I can just stuff them in my ear and the little rubber covers block out sound on their own. The aelec headphones come with a bunch of different size rubbery buds. The headphones also have acttive noise reduction, but I can’t actually tell if this is doing anything. You can’t turn it on or off, it’s always on, so it’s difficult to tell if it’s working. That being said, I’m on a plane right now listening to Pandora and it sounds pretty good.

As a test, I just switched to my cheap wired headeset, I’m still on the plane. I’m sorry to say that the wired headphones sound much better than the aelec headphones.

Poor sound quality

I must say I was pretty dissappointed when I first heard these headphones. There isn’t much bass at all. I’m not a huge fan of bass, but even I am unsatisfied with the sounds of these guys.

Neat Features

If you can get over the poor quality sound, the headphones seem to work very well with iOS. All the control buttons are on the right earbud. Press and hold to turn on or off. There are buttons for up and down volume. The power button also does pause play as well as forward and reverse. There is a small LED light that lets you know the headphones are on and connected. There is also some audio feedback. A voice will tell you that the headphones are connected or powering on. It seems to be speaking Chinese though. I heard it in English the first time I turned on the headphones, but lately it’s been speaking something else.

Charging and battery life

It comes with a little micro USB cable so you can charge the battery. The slot is well hidden in the right ear bud. It seems to be hidden and well located as to avoid getting wet in the rain. I haven’t run out of batter yet and I’ve used the headphones for a few hours. I was wondering if there was some way to find out the battery level. It turns out my iPhone displays a little battery meter next to the Bluetooth icon on the phone screen. See the image below.

Neck slide

When you wear these you have to decide if the cord goes in front of your neck or behind. Behind makes the most sense to me. If the wire is behind your neck, then you can easily puck out one or both of the buds and let them just dangle around your neck. If the wire was in front and you removed one earbud, then the entire contraption would be hanging from one earbud, which might not last very long. Of coure you can’t pluck out both earbuds with this configuration since it would just fall to the ground.

I do find that when I jog, the loose wire tends to work it’s way over to my right side and even starts pulling out the left ear bud. I’m not sure why this happens but it’s actually quite annoying. I wonder if it means that I’m lopsided somehow. Perhaps I’ll just have to try putting the wire in front and see if that solves the problem.

Worth it?

I got these for $25 on Amazon and at that price I would say yes, it’s worth it. I’m disappointed that the sound quality is so poor, even compared with my $5 headphones from TJ Maxx. I might try returning these and trying again when I upgrade to an iPhone 7.

item.title: shodan for finding webcams
item.description:
Shodan is an IoT search engine. It randomly connects to IP addresses on the internet and tries to talk to them. Most devices will return some kind of response, Shodan calls these banners. For instance, a web server banner looks like this:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: GitHub.com
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Last-Modified: Sat, 19 Nov 2016 12:08:21 GMT
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Expires: Sat, 19 Nov 2016 12:18:41 GMT
Cache-Control: max-age=600
X-GitHub-Request-Id: 17EB2E25:14B47:5F5B442:583040C9
Content-Length: 22124
Accept-Ranges: bytes
Date: Sat, 19 Nov 2016 12:09:35 GMT
Via: 1.1 varnish
Age: 54
Connection: keep-alive
X-Served-By: cache-iad2646-IAD
X-Cache: HIT
X-Cache-Hits: 1
X-Timer: S1479557375.340912,VS0,VE0
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Fastly-Request-ID: cdb3a353341adec9152ca6822791701da75cfac7

I got this header by running curl -D head http://blog.sensr.net, which does an HTTP GET to the given URL and saves the headers in a file, in this case named head. Since http://blog.sensr.net is hosted at GitHub, we can see that they run their own customer server software.

How many Github servers are there out there? The search github does the trick:

https://default-password.info/ https://cirt.net/passwords

How does Shodan get the screenshots?

https://images.shodan.io/?query=http will return the webcams images that Shodan has stored. rtsp has_screenshot:trueshould also return webcams that have screenshots. What is the difference between the these queries?

What does the webcam search actualy look for? It must be something in the header. There isn’t a way to look for multiple fields, the search is an ‘and’ right?

Ah, could look for query=rtsp and then it’s probably a camera.

o Extract image from RTSP

Build up a databse of banners that are webcams. Then try to get to the snapshot URL. Each camera model will have different urls. The ispycconnect.com site has a lot of options for connect urls. Use their configs to try different ones.

For foscam the snapshot url is something like : http://IP/snapshot.cgi

Can we use the webcam models that we found in the DB to find cameras on Shodan?

Can we use Shodan to test out new camera models for Sensr.net? Find an open camera and then set it up on Sensr.net.

this finds cameras that they have stored images from. Needed to subscribe, $45 per year. Student discounts available.

https://images.shodan.io/?query=http

I find cameras here but can’t seem to connect to them. Is there a way to use the API to find ones that are actually live?

o Maybe do a survey of the cameras that are open. I’m seeing images from Dlink and Vivotek only so far. Is vivotek in the banner somewhere?

Maybe look at the snapshot URL?

o Blog post about snapshot urls…

Vivotek: http://www.vivotek.com/faq/urlq03.html You can type URL command http:///cgi-bin/video.jpg to get the snapshot.

If you are using our new 7000 series and 8000 series cameras or video server, you can type another URL command http:///cgi-bin/viewer/video.jpg to get the snapshot.

So write a Shodan program that finds vivotek cameras then tries to go to the snapshot url.

http://99-57-193-245.lightspeed.knvltn.sbcglobal.net:7547/cgi-bin/video.jpg

Nope…

It’s mostly parking lots, so maybe write a blog post on how to record your parking lot camera…

Find cameras with rtsp and screenshot. Currently 771 results. rtsp has_screenshot:true

Lots or UBNT and Hipcam

good list of username and password

http://null-byte.wonderhowto.com/how-to/hack-like-pro-find-vulnerable-webcams-across-globe-using-shodan-0154830/

Run host command

Get the IP addresses of all our cameras and then run the host command

Chad’s IP 69.117.185.59:4567

Find Foscams

http://rampartssecurity.com/docs/Exploiting-Foscam-IP-Cameras.pdf

Additionally, as of firmware 11.37.2.54, the web server returned in the header is “Boa/0.94.13” instead of “Netwave IP Camera”.

Search for Boa/0.94.13 on shodan and find some return a header with DCS-xxx in them…

netwave IP camera: http://IP/snapshot.jpg?user=[USERNAME]&pwd=[PASSWORD]&strm=[CHANNEL]
